title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act titled "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for providing supportive housing to benefit veterans and their families. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can execute leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for supportive housing benefiting veterans and their families. This includes leases for services promoting health, wellness, education, and spiritual wellness for up to 50 years. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs can execute leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for supportive housing benefiting veterans and their families. The leases can be for up to 50 years to a third party to provide services that primarily benefit veterans and their families, including health promotion, education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, and volunteerism. Supportive housing leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus can provide services like education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, and volunteerism for veterans and their families. Services may also include family support, transportation, and other support services. Supportive housing leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus offer services such as education, vocational training, legal assistance, and volunteerism for veterans and their families. Additionally, services like family support, transportation, and other support services are provided. The Regents of the University of California may lease real property for up to 10 years on behalf of its UCLA campus. The Regents of the University of California may lease real property for up to 10 years at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus, with a focus on providing services to veterans. The Regents of the University of California can lease property at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for up to 10 years, focusing on providing services to veterans. The lease must align with the campus master plan, with veterans' services as the main focus, and The Regents must agree to offer additional services as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The Regents agrees to provide additional services and support during the lease term, benefiting veterans and their families, including those who are severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless. These services may include activities related to veterans' well-being. The Regents will provide services benefiting veterans and their families, including those who are severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless, through a medical affiliation agreement. Activities may cover medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling needs. The Regents will provide services for veterans and their families, including medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling needs. The Regents will maintain records documenting the value of these additional services for the duration of the lease. The Regents provides various services for veterans and their families, including medical, therapeutic, and counseling needs. Records documenting the value of these services must be maintained for the duration of the lease. The Secretary is limited in carrying out land-sharing agreements at the Campus unless they provide additional health-care resources. The Secretary must maintain records of the lease duration and make them available. Land-sharing agreements at the Campus must provide additional health-care resources and benefit veterans and their families. Revenues from leases at the Campus will be credited to the Secretary. The Secretary must maintain records of lease duration and make them available. Revenues from leases at the Campus will be credited to the applicable Department medical facilities account for renovation and maintenance without fiscal year limitation. Easements at the Campus provide additional health-care resources and benefit veterans and their families. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus to local or regional public transportation authorities for access and operation, in accordance with section 8124 of title 38, United States Code. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus to local or regional public transportation authorities and the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or any agency or public utility company for various purposes. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus to local or regional public transportation authorities, the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or any agency or public utility company for the purpose of providing public utilities and improving facilities. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus to local or regional public transportation authorities, the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or any public utility company for providing public utilities. Improvements proposed under the easement or right-of-way shall be subject to the Secretary's terms. Easements or rights-of-way authorized shall be terminated upon abandonment. Improvements proposed under authorized easements or rights-of-way shall be subject to Secretary's terms. Easements or rights-of-way will be terminated upon abandonment or nonuse, with land reverting to the United States. The Secretary is prohibited from selling the property. The Secretary is prohibited from selling or conveying fee simple title to any real property or improvements at the Campus. Leases must align with the approved master plan. The Secretary is prohibited from selling or conveying fee simple title to any real property or improvements at the Campus. Leases must align with the approved master plan and comply with all Federal laws relating to leases and land use as determined by the Inspector General. The Secretary may not enter into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus, or renew any such lease or land-sharing agreement that is not in compliance with Federal laws relating to leases and land use as determined by the Inspector General. If significant mismanagement is found regarding leases or land use at the Campus, the Secretary cannot enter into any non-compliant lease agreements until all audit recommendations are implemented. The Secretary must certify to relevant committees and representatives that all audit recommendations for leases at the Campus have been implemented. Leases must comply with federal laws on environmental and historic preservation. The Secretary must certify that audit recommendations for leases at the Campus have been implemented and comply with federal laws on environmental and historic preservation. A Community Veterans Engagement Board will be established within 180 days to coordinate activities on the Campus. The Secretary must certify audit recommendations for leases at the Campus have been implemented and comply with federal laws on environmental and historic preservation. A Community Veterans Engagement Board will be established within 180 days to coordinate activities on the Campus, identify community goals, and provide advice to improve services for veterans and their families. A Community Veterans Engagement Board will be established to coordinate activities on the Campus, identify community goals, and provide advice to improve services for veterans, members of the Armed Forces, and their families. The Board will be comprised of members, with at least 50 percent being veterans, and the rest being family members of veterans, veteran advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. The Community Veterans Engagement Board will have members determined by the Secretary, with at least 50 percent being veterans. Nonveteran members can be family members of veterans, veteran advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. The Board will provide opportunities for community collaboration and communication, including public forums on the Campus. The Community Veterans Engagement Board, with members determined by the Secretary, will include at least 50 percent veterans. Nonveteran members can be family members of veterans, veteran advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. The Board will provide opportunities for community collaboration and communication, focusing on local issues identified by the community such as health care, benefits, and memorial services at the Campus. The Secretary will notify Congress about lease agreements at the Campus, focusing on local issues like health care, benefits, and memorial services. The Secretary will notify Congress about lease agreements at the Campus, focusing on local issues like health care, benefits, and memorial services. Before entering into or renewing a lease or land-sharing agreement, the Secretary must notify the relevant committees and members of Congress representing the area at least 45 days in advance. Additionally, an annual report must be submitted one year after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary must notify Congress at least 45 days before entering into or renewing a lease agreement at the Campus. An annual report must be submitted to relevant committees and members of Congress representing the area where the Campus is located. The Secretary must annually submit a report to Congress evaluating all leases and land-sharing agreements at the Campus, including revenue management and required records. The Secretary must annually submit a report to Congress evaluating all leases and land-sharing agreements at the Campus, including revenue management and required records. The Inspector General is also required to submit reports two and five years after the enactment of the Act, and as deemed necessary thereafter. The Inspector General must submit reports on all leases at the Campus to Congress every two and five years after the Act's enactment, and as needed thereafter. The Inspector General must submit reports on all leases at the Campus to Congress every two and five years after the Act's enactment, and as needed thereafter. The Committee on Veterans' Affairs of the Senate, the House of Representatives, and relevant Members must receive a report on leases and land management at the Campus, including an assessment of the Department's efforts to implement the master plan. The Inspector General must submit reports on leases and land management at the Campus to Congress every two and five years after the Act's enactment, considering the Department's efforts to implement the master plan. The Inspector General must consider the Secretary's most recent report in preparing annual reports required by subparagraph (A). The Secretary is not limited in entering other authorized agreements regarding the Campus that are consistent with this section. The term "principally benefit veterans and their families" is defined in this section. The Secretary has the authority to enter into agreements regarding the Campus that are authorized by law and not inconsistent with this section. The term "principally benefit veterans and their families" is defined as services provided exclusively to veterans and their families or designed for their particular needs. The term "principally benefit veterans and their families" refers to services exclusively for veterans and their families or designed for their specific needs, excluding services that only benefit veterans. The term "principally benefit veterans and their families" refers to services exclusively for veterans and their families, excluding those that generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs generates revenue through services for veterans and their families. Amendments are made to prohibit property disposal and enhance-use leases. Amendments are made to prohibit property disposal and enhance-use leases under the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016.
